sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,Song III., in Poetical Essays, (Glasgow, 1788), 216-217.

head.title: Song III.11 First published as a separate song in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 216-217; reprinted as the first song in Turnbull’s comedy The Recruit, in Poems (1794), pp.38-39; and again with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

body.note: Tune. The mucking o’ Geordie’s byre.2

2 The air Turnbull used, “The Muckin’ o’ Geordie’s Byre,” had appeared in Orpheus Caledonius (1733), no. 33; Caledonian Pocket Companion, II (1745), p. 35; and (with earlier words) in Johnson, Scots Musical Museum, I (1787), no. 96; it was also used later by Burns for his song “Adown winding Nith I did wander” (Kinsley II:701), published in Thomson, Select Collection of Original Scotish Airs, II: set 3 (1799), song 66. The Recruit was first performed for Turnbull’s benefit performance in Dumfries in January, 1794. It was staged at the City Theatre, Church Street, Charleston, again for Turnbull’s benefit night, on March 11, 1796, and again at the Charleston Theatre, Broad Street, Charleston, on May 30, 1807.

lg.l: Ye lads that are plaguet wi’ lasses,
Had need to be tenty33 adj. attentive. and slie,
Or soon ye’ll be guidet like asses,
Gif ye be as silly as me.
I courtet a lassie for siller,44 n. silver.
And she was right saucy and sprie;
But ’gin I was buckl’d until her,
The fient a scrap siller had she.
But kent ye the way how I gat her,
Ye’d say it was cunning o’ me;
The chiels a’ gaed wood to be at her,
Sae cadgie55 adj. cheerful. the siller to see:
But I gied her something to carry,
A sure memorandum to be,
And syne she consentet to marry,
And wad hae nae ither but me.
In a doop66 In a moment (Jamieson, Etymological Dictionary of the Scots Langauge). she began to grow wally,77 adj. plump, big, buxom strong; in this case, pregnant.
The neebours a’ fairli’t to see;
But I kent the reason fu’ brawly,88 Very well.
Wha soon was a daddy to be.
And when the black cutty99 n. horse or mare of two years of age. we mountet,
Her lads a’ leugh hearty at me;
But O how my courage was bluntet,
When fient a scrap siller had she.
